result.markdown:
# Dot plots {.unnumbered} ::: {.callout-tip appearance='simple' icon=false} ***This graph is largely complete and just needs final proof reading.*** ::: :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false} ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #02577A;"} Graph info :::
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](dot_plots_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #02577A;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #282b2d;"} **✅ a numeric (continuous) variable** ::: :::: ## Description Dot-plots are similar to histograms and frequency polygons, except instead of using bars or lines, they use dots to represent the frequency (or count) of values for a given variable. ## Getting set up :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Packages ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Install packages. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by Allison Horst](www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} The `penguins` data ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins glimpse(penguins) #> Rows: 344 #> Columns: 8 #> $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, … #> $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen,… #> $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3… #> $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6… #> $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181… #> $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650… #> $ sex male, female, female, NA, female… #> $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 20… ``` ::: ::: :::: ## The grammar :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Code ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Create labels with `labs()` Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` Map `flipper_length_mm` to the `x` axis Add the `geom_dotplot()` layer Adjust the `dotsize` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_dotplot <- labs( title = "Adult foraging penguins", subtitle = "Distribution of flipper length", x = "Flipper length (millimeters)") ggp2_dotplot <- ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm)) + geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5) ggp2_dotplot + labs_dotplot ``` ::: ::: ### Graph ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](dot_plots_files/figure-html/create_graph_dotplot-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} A downside of using dot plots is the lack of interpretability of the `y` axis. ::: ::::
